s.text: It's true that returning veterans didn't get divorced in large numbers.
As his title suggests, Brokaw makes an explicit case for the superiority of the World War II generation.
"That's another legacy of the World War II generation, the strong commitment to family values and community," Brokaw writes in another characteristic passage.
The United States has probably become more religious as boomers have become the dominant demographic group.
Let's not forget that George Wallace and Joe McCarthy also served in World War II.

The challenge faced by the Vietnam generation was morally more complex: How do you serve your country when it is engaged in a morally dubious cause (a cause the country as a whole--not just a few protesters--came to conclude was a mistake)?
Both Brokaw (born in 1940) and Spielberg (born in 1946) evince a powerful sense of nostalgia for the world of their fathers.
"They faced great odds and a late start, but they did not protest ," Brokaw writes of the GIs, casting another aspersion at the Vietnam generation (italics mine).
"They faced great odds and a late start, but they did not protest ," Brokaw writes of the GIs, casting another aspersion at the Vietnam generation (italics mine).
Let's not forget that George Wallace and Joe McCarthy also served in World War II.
But that doesn't prove that our grandparents and parents had a deeper commitment to family values.
